Rheumatology
Joint aspiration: The most important investigation in any monoarthritic pres-
entation (table 12.2, see also OHCS p706). Send synovial ﬂ uid for urgent white cell 
count, Gram stain, polarized light microscopy (for crystals, p548), and culture. The 
risk of inducing septic arthritis, using sterile precautions, is <1:10 000. 2 Look for 
blood,3 pus, and crystals (gout or CPPD crystal arthropathy; p548). Do not at-
tempt joint aspiration through inﬂ amed and potentially infected skin (eg through 
a psoriatic plaque or overlying cellulitis).

*Eg trauma, tumour, or haemophilia.
Blood tests: FBC, ESR, urate, U&E, CRP. Blood culture for septic arthritis. Consider 
rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP, ANA, other auto antibodies (p553), and HLA B27 (p551) 
—as guided by presentation. Consider causes of reactive arthritis (p551), eg viral 
serology, urine chlamydia PCR, hepatitis and HIV serology if risk factors are present.
Radiology: Look for erosions, calciﬁ cation, widening or loss of joint space, chang-
es in underlying bone of aff ected joints (eg periarticular osteopenia, sclerotic ar-
eas, osteophytes). Characteristic X-ray features for various arthritides are shown 
in ﬁ gs 12.4–12.6. Irregularity of the sacroiliac joints is seen in spondyloarthritis. 
Ultrasound and MRI are more sensitive in identifying eff usions, synovitis, enthesitis 
and infection than plain radiographs—discuss further investigations with a radi-
ologist. Do a CXR for RA, vasculitis, TB, and sarcoid.
